g.text: 10 different templates devised for each task's prompt.
Each template has a natural language description of the task and
placeholders for the input and output exemplars
The variety of templates is to account for various ways of phrasing
the task and providing the exemplar
Exemplars in existing datasets converted to these templates as needed
apprach as problematic and introduce the notion of explicitly asking the LLM
to pick one among a set of classifications _(Options: Yes, No)_;
each task has a collection of datasets
of the 10 input templates previously created
perhaps one reason why GPT-3 struggles
with NLI is that NLI examples are unlikely to have appeared
naturally in an unsupervised training set and are thus awkwardly
phrased as a continuation of a sentence. For FLAN, we phrase
NLI as the more natural question “Does <premise> mean that
[#lightgreen] Mix all datasets and randomly sample from each dataset
multiple examples into a single sequence
Special EOS token seperates inputs from targets
Also good at instructions in general
Hold out each cluster for evaluation
while intruction tuning on remaining clusters
Evaluate the mean of performance on all templates
Also obtain test-set performance using the
Lower perf on co-ref: When downstream task is same as
original language modeling pre-training objective: i.e.,
first to do it at scale
to be worse than untuned model
